thread.title: A 'damaging' Brexit and the Discovery School: 5 big issues facing Newcastle's political leaders

author: Daniel Holland
title: A 'damaging' Brexit and the Discovery School: 5 big issues facing Newcastle's political leaders
text:

Polluted roads, failing free schools and troubled theatres will be among the key issues debated by Newcastle’s political leaders .
Newcastle City Council will be meeting at the Civic Centre on Wednesday evening, with the authority set to outline its stance on a series of major topics.
Here are just five of the debates councillors are expected to clash over from 6pm on Wednesday. Air pollution Heavy traffic on the A167 Central Motorway in Newcastle (Image: Newcastle Chronicle)
Lib Dem councillor Greg Stone has asked the council when it will be publishing a clean air plan to tackle pollution in the city.
In July last year, Newcastle was named among the areas of the UK that break legal pollution levels on some roads, with the Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs (Defra) pinpointing the A167 between the Tyne Bridge and the Swan House roundabout as the problem zone.
The council was ordered by Defra to produce an “innovative” plan to achieve legal Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2) levels, but is yet to publish its proposals. Discovery School closure Discovery School Blandford Street, Newcastle (Image: newcastle chronicle)
Teachers, students and parents were told earlier this month that Newcastle’s Discovery School would shut its doors for good by the end of August.
The flagship free school was slammed by Ofsted inspectors, while council leader Nick Forbes called the school’s failure a “damning indictment” of Government’s “high risk experiment” in academisation.
Coun Nora Casey, the council’s education chief, will bring forward a motion on Wednesday night calling on the Government to give local councils greater powers over academies and free schools and to stop giving “disproportionate” funding to the free school programme.
The council will also be debating the city’s annual education and skills report. Read More How a turbulent four years saw the Discovery School fall from high-tech hope to 'Inadequate' failure Theatres’ EU trouble
The city’s theatre bosses warned last week that they could face financial ruin because of new EU regulations requiring them to replace older light bulbs used in their lighting rigs.
The Tyne Theatre and Opera House, Northern Stage, Theatre Royal, Live Theatre and People’s Theatre all confirmed they will be hit by the changes - which could force them to pay out up to a million pounds on new equipment.
Labour’s Coun John-Paul Stephenson will call on the council to support the Save Stage Lighting campaign and lobby the EU to find a compromise. Srebrenica genocide
Members of Newcastle’s Bosnian community will be in the council chamber as Coun Rebecca Shatwell calls for the authority to remember the Srebrenica genocide, in which more than 8,000 Bosnian Muslims were killed by Serbian nationalist forces.
She will praise the way Newcastle has welcomed Bosnian refugees and the contributions they have made to the city. Read More North East businesses are 'exasperated' by Brexit talks, PM is told Brexit impact on the North East
Coun Wendy Taylor, a Lib Dem, will tell the chamber “there is mounting and indisputable evidence” of the damage that leaving the EU would cause the North East’s economy.
She will ask the council leader to write to local MPs and the Government calling for a vote to be held on the final Brexit deal, including an option for the UK to remain a full member of the EU. Like us on Facebook
